author: ralexstokes
content: FYI: proposal for a mev-boost circuit breaker to go into CLs ASAP https://hackmd.io/@ralexstokes/BJn9N6Thc

author: tersec
content:
is there a specific attack this is supposed to defend against? It seems reasonable, not not particularly difficult to implement, but https://hackmd.io/@ralexstokes/BJn9N6Thc#recovery-condition seems like it would eventually trigger on all but the most solid networks.

https://sepolia.beaconcha.in/ shows three missing blocks in a row frequently and four semi-regularly (at least a couple of times in the last few hours). that seems pretty close to the threshold of five

author: tersec
content: It's not clear if those are just reorgs though, which are covered by the proposal

author: ralexstokes
content: the final number could be higher

author: ralexstokes
content: but to answer your question, this is a mitigation against the scenario where the builder network fails to release blocks when they should

author: tersec
content: Isn't that what the 1 second timeout before using backup EL block construction is for?

author: ralexstokes
content: if there is a buggy or malicious relay, then they could fail to release the execution payload needed to form the full block

author: ralexstokes
content: in this setting the proposer has already signed the commitment

author: tersec
content: oh, that would be a problem, yes

author: ralexstokes
content: that timeout is in the event of a slow relay, more than a failing or even malicious relay

author: ralexstokes
content: hopefully we never need this breaker to trigger, but it would be good to have an absolute fail safe
